questions.text: What causes pellagra in Hartnup disease?

choices.text: Excessive loss of niacin in urine

questions.solution:
Malabsorption of tryptophan leads to pellagra in Hartnup disease.

In Hartnup disease, there is defective membrane transport of tryptophan along with other amino acids and large losses of tryptophan in the intestine and kidneys.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Casal’s necklace:

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the vagina is ________
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the vagina is non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

The stratified squamous epithelia are subdivided into two types: keratinized and non-keratinized.

Keratinized epithelium: It is present over the surface that is subjected to high levels of abrasion and drying.

It is seen in:

  • Entire epidermis
  • Mucocutaneous junction of the lips, nostrils, distal anal canal, the outer surface of the tympanic membrane
  • Parts of the oral cavity: gingivae, hard palate and filiform papillae on the anterior part of the dorsal surface of the tongue

Non-keratinized epithelium: It is present over the surface that is subjected to abrasion but not drying.

It is seen in:

  • The lining of the oral cavity except the parts mentioned above
  • Oropharynx and laryngopharynx
  • Esophagus
  • Part of the anal canal
  • Vagina
  • Distal uterine cervix
  • Distal urethra
  • Cornea
  • Inner surfaces of the eyelids
  • Vestibule of the nasal cavities

questions.text: A patient was prescribed an antipsychotic drug following which he developed parkinsonism. Which of the following drugs​ can be given?
questions.solution:
Trihexyphenidyl is the drug of choice for drug-induced parkinsonism. It is a central anticholinergic.

Drug-induced parkinsonism is a condition caused by certain drugs having D2 antagonistic action (typical antipsychotics). The decrease in dopaminergic activity results in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Anticholinergics act by restoring the balance.

questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had a history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun, severe freckling in the sun-exposed areas. The autosomal recessive condition responsible for this is due to:
questions.solution:
The image shows a girl with Xeroderma Pigmentosum. It is characterized by Defective Nucleotide Excision repair that is transmitted autosomal recessively

Clinical Features:

Typical 3 stage Progression.

Child is asymptomatic at birth. Diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle like areas over the sun exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.

Poikiloderma is a characteristic feature of the second stage. Poikiloderma results in skin atrophy, telangiectasias with mottled hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation.

In the third stage appearance of cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Related Pearl: Important DNA Repair Disorders Associated with Cutaneous Features

Disorder

DNA Repair Defect

Xeroderma pigmentosum

Nucleotide excision repair

Cockayne syndrome

Nucleotide excision repair

Trichothiodystrophy

Nucleotide excision repair

Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Bloom syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Werner syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Ataxia telangiectasia

Double strand break repair

Fanconi anaemia

Interstrand cross‐link repair

Muir–Torre syndrome

Mismatch repair

questions.text: Which of the following type of ion channels is predominantly responsible for phase 0 of the given action potential?
questions.solution:
The graph in the given image represents the action potential of the SA node (i.e., the pacemaker potential). In the figure, phase 0 corresponds to the impulse/upstroke and, this is predominantly due to the opening of 'L' (long-acting) type of calcium channels resulting in an intracellular movement of the calcium ions down its electrochemical gradient.

The pacemaker potential consists of:

  • Phase 0 - this is an upstroke seen due to the opening of 'L' type, voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. This causes an influx of calcium leading to the upstroke.
  • Phase 3 - This is followed by the inactivation of the calcium channels and the simultaneous activation of K+ channels. This leads to the efflux of K+ bringing about repolarization.
  • Phase 4- As the K+ efflux is increased, the pacemaker fibre is pulled to a state of hyperpolarization. Once this state is reached, because of the high extracellular concentrations of the sodium ions, they tend to move slowly into the fibre, thus causing a slow rise in the RMP on the positive side.
    • As these sodium channels get activated in the state of hyperpolarisation they are called the "h" channel or funny channel. 
    • A similar type of calcium channel called "T" (transient) type joins together with the funny channels and completes this phase

The slope of Phase 4 in the SA node determines the heart rate.

questions.text: A deceased male was posted for a ​post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.solution:
The lymph nodes should be examined in this case.

Some amount of material or dye used for creating tattoo marks is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Hence in cases where a tattoo mark has disappeared naturally or has been removed, the lymph nodes must be examined before making any conclusions.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all except :
questions.solution:
Fingerprint pattern differs in identical twins.

The pattern of the fingerprint comprises arches, loops, whorls or combinations of these three patterns, this is unique to every individual and does not match even for identical twins.

questions.text: The muscle marked as " B" in the image is ______ and is innervated by ______
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is inferior oblique and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is true about “posthumous child”?

choices.text: The child is delivered after death of biological father
The child is abandoned by the parents

questions.solution:
A posthumous child is a child delivered after the death of the biological father or child delivered after the death of the biological mother, usually delivered by a Caesarean section.

  • Illegitimate child or a bastard: A child born 'out of wedlock'.
  • Supposititious child or fictitious child: A woman may pretend pregnancy and delivery, and later produce a living child as her own for obtaining money or for the purpose of claiming the property.

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder presented with fatigue on moderate exercise. He had recently started eating raw eggs for protein. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.

Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white, develop biotin deficiency and as a result deficiency of the carboxylase enzymes. This is because a protein called, avidin present in the egg-white binds to biotin in the diet, and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption.

Biotin deficiency can cause:

  • Dermatitis
  • Mental status changes (depression, hallucinations)
  • Paraesthesia
  • Alopecia

Biotin serves as co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as:

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase
  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
  • Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Vitamin

Deficiency State

Thiamine (B1)

Beriberi

questions.text: The resting membrane potential of a nerve fibre depends on ______
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a nerve fibre depends on the diffusion of both K+ and Na+ and the Na+-K+ ATPase pump.

The most predominant factor, however, is the diffusion of K+ ions. This is because, at rest, the permeability of the membrane of the nerve fibre to K+ ions is almost 100 times greater than that to Na+. 

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

Tissue

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: The most commonly fractured bone among the carpal bones is:
questions.solution:
The most commonly fractured bone is Scaphoid which is denoted by 1 in the image.

Relative incidence of carpal Bone Fracture - Scaphoid > Triquetrum > Trapezium.

Avascular necrosis is a common complication of scaphoid frcature.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

Functions of pili:

  • Adhesins located at the tip of pili help in bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells.
  • They help in resistance to phagocytosis.
  • It is made up of antigenic pilin proteins that are responsible for the immune response.
  • Pili gives twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Sex pili help in bacterial conjugation through which transfer of genetic material occurs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pacemaker of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

NOTE:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the Interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: The mode of inheritance in Marfan syndrome is ___________
questions.solution:
Marfan’s syndrome is an autosomal-dominantly inherited connective tissue disorder.

  • It involves primarily the ocular, cardiovascular, and skeletal systems.
  • The condition results from heterozygous mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene located on chromosome 15 at band q21.1 (15q21.1), which encodes for the glycoprotein fibrillin.
  • Fibrillin is a major building block of microfibrils, which constitute the structural components of the suspensory ligament of the ocular lens and serve as substrates for elastin in the aorta and other connective tissues.

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that can be scraped off and it develops over the tongue, lips, gum, or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include high levels of glucose, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Other options:

  • Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue and cannot be scraped off.
  • Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.
  • Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx.

questions.text: A  patient with gout develops hypertension  The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following drugs should not be administered?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazides should not be given to this patient.

Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and also increases uric acid reabsorption, thus it may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman diagnosed with tubercular meningitis has a peculiar breathing pattern described as irregular and rapid, with rhythmical pauses lasting 10-30s, as shown below. What is the pattern of breathing?
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing in the case presented is Biot's breathing.

Also known as ataxic breathing, it is associated with increased intracranial pressure and meningitis.

The pattern of breathing is irregular and rapid with rhythmical pauses lasting for 10–30 seconds.

Sometimes, it has alternating periods of apnea and tachypnea. This pattern typically lacks the crescendo-decrescendo cycles which are seen in Cheyne-Stokes breathing. It is sometimes called as the atrial fibrillation of respiration.

Other options:

  • Cheyne-Stokes Breathing: characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnoea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia.
  • Kussmaul’s Breathing: It is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually implies metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with Ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes rapid-onset food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

The common sources of infection are foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source

Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice

Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period

Vibrio parahemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: The following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of which condition?
questions.solution:
In the given darrow yannet diagram, there is hypoosmostic volume expansion which is suggestive of SIADH.

  • In SIADH there is excessive secretion of ADH. So, excess water is retained in the body.
  • So, ECF volume rises. ECF osmolality decreases.
  • ECF fluid enters ICF untill osmotic equilibrium is re-established.
  • So, ICF volume rises. ICF osmolality decreases.

The Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions are shown above.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium in the urinary bladder.

The deepest layer has columnar cells, the middle layers are made up of polyhedral cells and the surface layer has cells that are large and shaped like an umbrella.

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: While going through the echo reports of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China you see she has dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following nutritional disease can explain her condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is the characteristics, may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium:

Selenium is an important trace element which is a part of the 21st amino acid Selenocysteine.

There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant which complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Clinical correlation:

  • Keshan disease - Endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low.
  • Kashin-Beck disease -  Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy due to selenium deficiency seen in regions of China and Russia. 
  • Selenium toxicity - Chronic ingestion of high amounts of selenium leads to selenosis. It is characterized by hair and nail brittleness, garlic breath odor, myopathy, irritability, and other abnormalities of the nervous system.

questions.text: Angiotensin II causes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Vasodilation is not caused by Angiotensin II. On the contrary, it is a powerful arteriolar vasoconstrictor.

 

Actions of Angiotensin II
  • Produces powerful arteriolar constriction and a rise in SBP and DBP
  • Acts directly on the adrenal cortex to increase aldosterone secretion
  • Facilitates the release of Norepinephrine by a direct action on postganglionic sympathetic neurons
  • Contraction of mesangial cells with a resultant decrease in GFR
  • Direct effect on renal tubules to increase Na+ reabsorption
  • Acts on brain to decrease sensitivity of baroreceptor reflex, potentiating the pressor effect of AT II
  • Acts on brain to increase water intake and increase secretion of ADH and ACTH

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short term treatment to relieve the symptoms?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin is the drug used to relieve the symptoms in cases of postoperative urinary retention in a patient with COPD.

Uses:

It is efficacious in the treatment of Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) with little effect on blood pressure. 

Other options:

Option B- Bethanechol is the drug of choice to relieve the symptoms in cases of postoperative urinary retention in a patient. However, it can cause bronchoconstriction in patients with COPD. Hence tamsulosin is the best answer here.

Option C- Terazosin is α1 receptor antagonists, used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). 

Option D- Methacholine is also a muscarinic agonist but acts specifically on bronchial smooth muscle causing its contraction. It is available as an inhalational agent and is used for the diagnosis of bronchial hyper-reactivity in patients who do not have clinically apparent asthma.

questions.text: A 48-year old non-diabetic obese man presented for routine follow up. On investigation, his lipid profile showed hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated LDL, and VLDL. Which of the following vitamins can be used as a lipid-lowering agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
The vitamin that can be used as a lipid-lowering agent is nicotinic acid (niacin or vitamin B3).

Niacin causes a reduction in LDL, VLDL and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL. It is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein (a) levels significantly.

The main adverse effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing and pruritus. It can be controlled by pretreatment with aspirin. In patients with diabetes mellitus, niacin should be used cautiously because niacin induced insulin resistance can lead to hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a holocrine gland?
questions.solution:
Sebaceous gland is a holocrine type of gland.

The exocrine glands are classified into 3 types, depending on the mode of secretion:

  • Merocrine glands (eccrine or epicrine glands): the secretions are released out of the cell through a process called exocytosis with the cell remaining intact, e.g. eccrine sweat glands, salivary glands, exocrine pancreas, secretion of milk protein casein by mammary glands.
  • Apocrine glands: the apical parts of the cells are shed off to discharge the secretion. e.g., sweat glands in axilla and anogenital regions and secretion of milk fat by mammary glands.
  • Holocrine glands: the entire cell disintegrates while discharging its secretion. It is typically seen in sebaceous glands.

Related Pearl: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature

Apocrine sweat gland

Eccrine sweat gland

Activity

Active at puberty

Throughout life

Opening on the surface

Around hair shaft

Through sweat pores

Function

Provides peculiar odour

Maintains temperature

Nervous control

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are adrenergic

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are cholinergic

Secretions

Viscid with lipids and proteins

Watery with salts

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called?
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

Examples of metaplasia include:

  • Columnar to squamous epithelium (also called squamous metaplasia):
    • This is the most common type of metaplasia, and is usually seen in the respiratory tract in cases of chronic smoking or sometimes in vitamin A deficiency,
    • It may also be present in cases where there are stones in the excretory ducts of salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, where, the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Squamous to columnar epithelium (also called columnar metaplasia): It is seen in Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Connective tissue metaplasia: It refers to the formation of bone, cartilage, or adipose tissue in the tissues where they are normally absent. One such example is myositis ossificans, a condition where there is the formation of bone within the muscle.

questions.text: Which type of bonding do the branching points in glycogen structure have?
questions.solution:
Branching points in glycogen structure have  α1 → 6 glucosidic bond.

  • Glycogen is the storage polysaccharide in animals.
  • It consists of α-D glucopyranose residues (in α1 → 4 glucosidic linkage in straight chains) with branching by means of α1 → 6 glucosidic bonds.

questions.text: Identify the hormone demonstrating the depicted fluctuations:
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM Sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by ________
questions.solution:
Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

Testosterone is synthesized from cholesterol in the Leydig cells and also from androstenedione secreted by the adrenal cortex.

The diagnosis of testosterone deficiency should be made only on the basis of clinical signs and symptoms consistent with androgen deficiency, and consistently subnormal serum testosterone concentrations at 8 to 10 AM on three occasions. 

Testosterone has been used to treat primary or secondary hypogonadism in adult men.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CSF sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci. 

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

questions.text: In a civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.solution:
In the case of civil negligence, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence. To prove negligence, all the following four elements must be present:

  • Duty: A duty of care by the doctor must exist.
  • Dereliction: The physician must maintain the standard of a 'prudent physician' under similar circumstances. If the physician fails to maintain the standard of care, it is called dereliction.
  • Direct causation: The negligent act or omission must directly cause the injury without any intervening cause.
  • Damage: The negligent act must cause damage of a type that would have been foreseen by a reasonable physician.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.

It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection.

Subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus. These include:

Subcutaneous mycoses

 Causative agent/s

Sporotrichosis

 Sporothrix schenckii
Chromoblastomycosis

Phialophora verrucosa

Fonsecaea pedrosoi

Fonsecaea compacta

Rhinocladiella aquaspersa

Cladophialophora carrionii

Phaeohyphomycosis

Exophiala jeanselmei

Phialophora richardsiae

Bipolaris spicifera

Wangiella dermatitidis

Mycetoma

 Pseudallescheria boydii (Anamorph Scedosporium apiospermum).

Madurella mycetomatis

Madurella grisea

E jeanselmei

Acremonium falciforme

Other options:

The fungi mentioned in options b, c, and d causes endemic mycosis. The disease is initiated in the lungs due to the inhalation of spores.

questions.text: The mechanism of resistance by lactamases​ to β-lactam antibiotics is by:
questions.solution:
Resistance by lactamases is through the degradation of antibiotics.

Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivates β-lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring in their structure.

However, the resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactamase is conferred through one of the four mechanisms.

  • Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
  • Modification of target PBPs
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs
  • Antibiotic efflux

questions.text: A patient has a hematocrit level of 40% and renal plasma flow of 600 mL/min. Calculate the renal blood flow.
questions.solution:
The renal blood flow is 1000 mL/min.

Renal blood flow (RBF) = Renal plasma flow/(1-Hematocrit)

= RPF / (1-Hct)

= 600 / (1-0.4)

= 600 / 0.6

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's Chorea?

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.solution:
Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat (>40) expansion mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (second to the third decade). Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen.  Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.

Treatment consists of haloperidol, tetrabenazine (Dopamine depletion).

 

Disease Repeats Clinical features
Fragile X- syndrome   CGG Mental retardation, large ears, and jaws, macroorchidism in males

Myotonic Dystrophy

(chromosome 19)

   CTG Muscle loss, cardiac arrhythmia,
cataracts, frontal balding
Huntington’s disease   CAG Affective disorder
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1   CAG Progressive ataxia, dysarthria,
dysmetria
Friedreich's ataxia   GAA Progressive ataxia,
dysarthria, hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity.

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. 
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

Quantitative culture:

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF), which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. 

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells. This is not seen in folic acid deficiency.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male was diagnosed with a tumor in the right submandibular gland and was posted for surgical removal of the gland and its duct.  During the procedure, which of the following nerves is susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Lingual nerve loops around the submandibular duct, and hence is susceptible to injury during the procedures involving the excision of the submandibular gland or its duct.

Superficial to the hyoglossus muscle, the submandibular duct lies between lingual and hypoglossal nerves. At the anterior border of the hyoglossus, it is crossed by the lingual nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is an inhibitor of RNA synthesis. It binds to the beta subunit of DNA dependent RNA-polymerase (rpoB) to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. The binding suppresses the chain formation in RNA synthesis.

5-Fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthesis.

Nitrofurantoin produces highly reactive intermediates that cause DNA damage.

Novobiocin is a potent inhibitor of bacterial DNA gyrase.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with angina. Coronary angiography revealed a block in the right coronary artery. The condition is likely to cause a ​decrease in blood supply through all of the following blood vessels except:
questions.solution:
Circumflex artery is not a branch of the right coronary artery. It is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The branches of the right coronary artery are:

  • Right conal artery - It is the first branch of the right coronary artery
  • Artery of the SA node 
  • Right marginal artery 
  • Posterior interventricular (descending) artery (in 65% population)
  • Atrial and anterior and posterior ventricular branches
The branches of the left coronary artery are:
  • The left anterior descending artery (Anterior interventricular branch of LCA)
  • Circumflex artery and its left marginal branch.

questions.text: Glucose transporter in the myocytes, under the influence of insulin, is ________
questions.solution:
Glucose transporter in the myocytes, under the influence of insulin, is GLUT 4.

Glucose transport in our body mainly occurs through sodium-independent glucose transporters, which include GLUT transporters, and to a small extent through sodium-dependent glucose transporters, which include SGLT-1 and SGLT-2. Insulin induces the movement of intracellular GLUT 4 molecules to the cell surface and thus increases glucose uptake.

Related Pearl: Glucose transporters and their locations

Tissue location Function
GLUT 1
Brain, RBC, Placenta, kidney, colon Basal glucose uptake
GLUT 2
Liver, pancreatic beta cell, small intestine, kidney Rapid uptake/release of glucose. Low affinity and high km
GLUT 3
Neurons, kidney, placenta High affinity for glucose
GLUT 4
Heart, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue Insulin-dependent glucose uptake
GLUT 5
Small intestine, testis, sperm Fructose transporter
GLUT 8
Blastocyst, testis, brain Insulin-dependent glucose uptake in blastocyst. Transports glucose to Mature spermatozoa.
GLUT 9
Liver, kidney Urate transporter

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic. The intern has administered an analgesic, following which the pain got aggravated. Which of the following could be responsible for the aggravation of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Morphine is the analgesic that could be responsible for the aggravation of the patient's symptoms. It causes constriction of the sphincter of Oddi causing an increase in fluid pressure in the common bile duct and gall bladder.

Diclofenac, Naproxen, and Etoricoxib are all NSAIDs that are used as an analgesic for mild to moderate pain. NSAIDs do not worsen the pain in patients with biliary colic.

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in prostate carcinoma.

Metastatic tumors of bone:

Metastatic tumors are the most common form of skeletal malignancy, greatly outnumbering primary bone cancers. The red marrow in these areas, with its rich capillary network and slow blood flow, facilitates implantation and growth of the tumor cells.

The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Furthermore, some cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other.

For example, prostatic adenocarcinoma is predominantly blastic whereas carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract and malignant melanoma produce lytic lesions.

questions.text: A patient has been brought to your emergency department with the following signs and symptoms - Dry mouth, irrelevant slurred speech, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical syndrome in the question is that of Datura poisoning.

  • Jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

  • All Datura species contain the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine.

  • Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked and produce delirium, hallucinations, and seizures along with other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia.

  • Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

  • Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in:

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic, has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal glucose - 49 mg/dL, elevated uric acid levels in the blood, and marked lactic acidosis. The blood sample has the following appearance. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia (milky white plasma), hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia)

Signs and symptoms of von Gierke disease are:

  • Seizures 
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes:

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch (as this is catabolized also by the debranching enzyme).
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Nicotinic acid, fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Related Pearl: Glycogen Storage Diseases

Disease

Symptoms

Hyperlipidemia

GSD type Ib

GSD type II

(Acid maltase)

GSD type III

(Limit dextrinosis)

Death at age ~5 years

Second wind phenomenon

Liver glycogen phosphorylase

Generally benign

questions.text: The inheritance pattern of hemophilia  A is ______
questions.solution:
Hemophilia A is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait and thus, affects mainly males and homozygous females.

Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. Hemophilia C, on the other hand, is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait.
